executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

Mouthwash producers have endured considerable volatility in recent years. The state of the economy directly impacts mouthwash sales, as consumers opt to postpone making discretionary purchases, including mouthwash, when macroeconomic conditions are unfavorable. During the early stages of the pandemic, sales were negatively impacted by jumping unemployment and weaker demand for dental care. In recent years, producers benefited from employment levels moving toward pre-pandemic levels and rising health expenditure, although elevated inflation and growing uncertainty in 2024 have led to further revenue losses. Manufacturers have been negatively impacted by significant supply chain disruptions in recent years, which, combined with volatile input prices, have contributed to rising purchase costs. Higher purchase costs and weaker demand for mouthwashes have placed downward pressure on profit. As a result, revenue is set to weaken at an estimated CAGR of 2.4% to $2.5 billion through the end of 2024, including a 0.4% dip that year alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Mouthwash Manufacturers Grapple With Economic Fluctuations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many consumers consider mouthwash a discretionary purchase, skipping the purchase when macroeconomic conditions are unfavorable, including times of low disposable income and heightened uncertainty. As a result, sales benefit from a positive macroeconomic landscape.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Producers Adapt To Changing Consumer Preferences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Mouthwash producers have benefited from consumers becoming increasingly health-conscious, with many prioritizing health check-ups and creating routines. These healthier habits include developing care routines, many of which include mouthwash.

Producers of oral care products can struggle with brand differentiation. Well-established brands like Listerine and Colgate are popular among consumers, making smaller, less-known producers allocate more resources toward promoting their mouthwash.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mouthwash Producers Are Set to Flourish as Economic Conditions Improve
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improved macroeconomic conditions are set to benefit producers, particularly as disposable income swells and consumers become more confident about the state of the economy. These trends are likely to boost sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Manufacturers Will Continue to Adapt to Heightened Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Niche luxury oral care brands will continue penetrating the market, with many capitalizing on digital channels. Growing competition limits pricing power for major mouthwash producers, but manufacturers will focus on maintaining market share to balance overall profitability.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Trade Activity Will Gain Traction, Although Its Impact Will Remain Small
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The expected depreciation of the dollar will support domestic producers by making US-produced mouthwash comparatively more affordable overseas, enabling exports to inch upward as a share of revenue.

industry_definition: The Mouthwash Manufacturing industry manufactures mouthwash, gargles, rinses and dentifrices.
key_trends: Small producers struggle to stand out against major producers like Listerine, Crest and Colgate. Their strong brand recognition and aggressive marketing help them overshadow smaller manufacturers.
Producers appealing to the luxury oral care market are finding success. These producers offer mouthwash with value-added features, appealing to consumers looking for more specialized solutions.
Economic uncertainty slows down mouthwash sales. When people tighten their finances, many postpone buying mouthwash, making producers highly reliant on a favorable macroeconomic environment.
To appeal to a broader pool of potential buyers, brands like Listerine have introduced unique flavors, like green tea for Asia and alcohol-free options for Muslim-majority countries.

Listerine has invested in product development to cater to consumers in emerging markets. This includes introducing flavors like green tea for Asian customers and alcohol-free options for Muslim-majority regions.

Big brands like Listerine and Colgate benefit from customer loyalty. These brands' strong reputations and quality products make customers willing to pay more, enabling producers to charge higher prices and grow profit.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Warehouse stores are large-scale retail outlets that offer various products and encourage bulk purchases through discounts. These lower prices and the long shelf life of mouthwash makes warehouse stores highly attractive to consumers.

Pharmacies and drug stores account for a smaller portion of revenue. Many consumers leverage these stores to restock health-related products, including mouthwash. Most consumers don't visit pharmacies often, making them less convenient than grocery stores.

E-commerce refers to online sales platforms like Amazon, where consumers can enjoy fast shipping and contactless delivery. Consumer preferences have made e-commerce the fastest-growing market for mouthwash producers.
Other channels include brick-and-mortar retailers and professionals, such as dentists.

products_and_services.product_description: Anticavity mouthwashes primarily use antiseptic ingredients to help treat or prevent tooth cavities. Fluoride-containing mouthwashes are the only products the Food and Drug Administration approved to treat or prevent cavities.

Antiseptic mouthwashes, both alcohol-based and alcohol-free, kill bacteria and eliminate plaque, refresh users' breath and support oral health. Active ingredients vary across different vendor brands, although common ingredients include cetylpyridinium chloride (CPC), triclosan and phenols, such as menthol and thymol.
Consumers use breath fresheners, or cosmetic mouthwashes, to freshen breath, prevent or alleviate cavities, reduce plaque or prevent gingivitis and other gum-related diseases.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Although mouthwash is generally affordable, it is still a discretionary product for many consumers. When disposable income swells, some consumers buy mouthwash when they otherwise wouldn't. Similarly, consumers are more likely to buy more expensive products when disposable income increases, supporting revenue growth. Weaker per capita disposable income poses a potential threat to mouthwash producers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Importers Benefit From a Rising US Dollar
international_trade_points.trade_description: The value of the US dollar has appreciated in recent years, making imported products comparatively more affordable to domestic buyers and enabling them to satisfy a larger share of domestic demand.
Canadian and Mexican producers benefit from the USMCA, which lowers trade barriers between the member countries. Because of this, Mexico and Canada account for more than half of imported mouthwash.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Don't Play a Significant Role in the Industry
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports have grown as a share of revenue in recent years despite the appreciation of the US dollar, largely driven by a sharper decline in domestic demand and the popularity of US brands overseas.

international_trade_points.trade_title: CANADA AND MEXICO ARE THE MOST POPULAR EXPORT DESTINATIONS
international_trade_points.trade_description: The most common destinations for exports are Canada and Mexico. The geographic proximity and favorable trade conditions between these countries allow for significant business and trade growth.

business_locations.location_description: The West, particularly California, is the leading hub for the oral care industry in the United States. The region is home to the largest concentration of manufacturers, with one-quarter of them basing operations in California. Remaining within proximity to downstream markets helps manufacturers save on transportation costs, resulting in lower operating costs.

New Jersey houses Johnson & Johnson, the largest manufacturer in the industry. As a result, New Jersey ranks third for the number of oral care manufacturers in the United States. Access to chemical manufacturers and crucial shipping ports supports both domestic shipping and international exports. This proximity enables producers to establish relationships with key suppliers while setting strong distribution channels.

The Southeast holds the largest share of the population. The region is home to notable cities like Atlanta and Miami, which have millions of consumers of oral care products. Florida's ports facilitate both importing cost-effective suppliers and exporting to other countries. The oral care sector has a significant presence in the region because of these logistic advantages and market demands.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) sets standards for over-the-counter drugs, including mouthwash products, through monographs. These monographs cover the proper dose and concentration of ingredients and approved health claims for packaging and labeling. Manufacturers using well-studied and safe active ingredients can market their products without.

According to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), mouthwash manufacturers must ensure their marketing and labeling claims are factual and based on scientific evidence. Misleading or deceptive claims can result in civil lawsuits or criminal action by the FTC. Manufacturers must provide substantiated evidence for their product claims, ensuring that consumers receive accurate information. This regulation helps maintain honesty and transparency in advertising.

The American Dental Association (ADA) evaluates the safety and effectiveness of oral health products, including mouthwash. Products meeting ADA standards are granted the "Seal of Acceptance," which influences consumer choice and indicates a commitment to quality and safety. This seal indicates to consumers that the product has been thoroughly tested and deemed effective for its intended use.

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) assures safe and healthful working conditions by setting and enforcing standards. This affects mouthwash production as manufacturers must comply with OSHA's regulations to ensure their facilities are safe for workers. This compliance may involve ergonomic assessments, chemical safety and proper protective equipment. Adherence to OSHA standards helps prevent workplace injuries and ensures a safe production environment.

basis_points.basis_title: Small producers struggle against major producers
basis_points.basis_description: Small producers struggle to stand out against major producers like Listerine, Crest and Colgate. Their strong brand recognition and aggressive marketing help them overshadow smaller manufacturers.
Producers appealing to the luxury oral care market are finding success. These producers offer mouthwash with value-added features, appealing to consumers looking for more specialized solutions.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Major manufacturers, such as Listerine, Crest Pro-Health, Colgate and Scope, dominate the industry. These brands have developed strong brand recognition, enabling them to dominate the industry.

Strong marketing and promotional activities by these large producers have supported them in capturing a larger share of the market. These efforts have resulted in consumers prioritizing brand recognition over affordable prices when shopping.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Mouthwash manufacturers' profit is comparatively higher than other personal care products. This is largely because of the discretionary nature and strong brand preferences impacting the industry.

Unfavorable macroeconomic conditions in recent years, including heightened consumer uncertainty, have pushed consumers to lower discretionary purchases like mouthwash and placed downward pressure on profit.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Labor Costs Rise Amid R&D Investments
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Although the production process is highly automated, producers continue to rely on skilled workers to operate machinery, develop new products, manage operating facilities and offer customer service.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Account for the Single-Largest Cost for Mouthwash Producers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like in other manufacturing industries, purchase costs account for the majority of revenue. Producers must buy inputs like water, alcohol, fluoride, essential oils, colorings and other chemical compounds.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Mouthwash manufacturing is capital-intensive, driven by the need for substantial machinery investment. While smaller companies tend to invest more in human labor, scaling up production requires manufacturers to acquire costly equipment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: LEVERAGING NEW INGREDIENTS IS CRUCIAL FOR INNOVATIVE
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Producers developing premium mouthwash have focused on using a broad range of ingredients to develop new products with value-added features. Modern mouthwashes now include Lactobacillus strains to support a balanced oral microbiome.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Many Consumers Consider Mouthwash a Discretionary Product
volatility_points.volatility_description: Mouthwash is largely considered a discretionary product, so sales are reliant on the state of the US economy and changes in macroeconomic factors like disposable income and consumer confidence.
Consumers can opt to just use toothpaste if economic conditions push them to do so. Being able to substitute mouthwash with relative ease makes sales highly reliant on macroeconomic conditions.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: LEVERAGING NEW INGREDIENTS IS CRUCIAL FOR INNOVATIVE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Producers developing premium mouthwash have focused on using a broad range of ingredients to develop new products with value-added features. Modern mouthwashes now include Lactobacillus strains to support a balanced oral microbiome.

Other ingredients include innovative enzymes, which enable mouthwashes to target and eradicate dental biofilms, tackling plaque and gum disease. Enzyme-infused mouthwashes target and break down plaque biofilm more efficiently than mechanical brushing alone, contributing to cleaner teeth and appealing to increasingly health-conscious buyers.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Growing import penetration impacts producers by capturing a large share of the domestic market. Prominent brand preferences have prevented imported mouthwash from taking over the industry.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Mouthwash is not as widely accepted as an integral part of oral hygiene as other oral health products, so demand is somewhat discretionary and moves in line with the overall economy.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Mouthwash producers serve retailers nationwide, so proximity to shipping networks is a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Due to stiff competition for market share, major companies in the industry have poured money into products that can stand out for their oral health benefits.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Despite automation in the industry, wage costs have increased due to mouthwash manufacturers' research and development efforts.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Price competition is significant, providing significant advantages to companies that can employ technology to reduce operating costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Mouthwash manufacturers sometimes deal with hazardous chemicals, which represents their most significant employee safety liability.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The American Dental Association provides its stamp of approval to mouthwashes with oral health benefits, which helps industry products gain legitimacy.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your company's buyers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Given the importance of big-box retailers to the industry, a single customer can account for a substantial share of a company's sales, and customer retention is vital.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins range widely between small private-label manufacturers and the major consumer brands that dominate the industry.

FAQs.question: Do you currently work with valuable brand names? How do you promote these to your customers?
FAQs.answer: Companies that establish valuable brand names, such as Colgate or Listerine, are able to attract and retain loyal customers and may be able to elevate prices, boosting profit.

FAQs.question: What measures do you take to develop new products? How do you stay ahead of your competition?
FAQs.answer: Mouthwash manufacturers that innovate and develop new products may be able to attract new consumers or entice buyers away from established industry product lines.

FAQs.question: How do you retain low supply costs?
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs account for nearly half of an average industry company's annual revenue. Companies that are able to lock in low supply costs will be able to avoid production inconsistencies and gain higher profitability.

FAQs.question: Do you keep track of the TWI? How do you respond to a decrease in the trade weighted index?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the trade-weighted index (TWI) will likely threaten industry growth, as an appreciation of the US dollar will cause imported products to.

FAQs.question: How will you cater to an increase in demand from dentists? What measures do you take to promote dental care products?
FAQs.answer: Growth in the Dentists industry in the US corresponds to increased consumer investment in dental health.

FAQs.question: How will you take advantage of a rise in per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Although mouthwash is generally affordable, it is still a discretionary product for many consumers.
